Best Bet

Richard Pearson Thomas is a composer and a member of South Country Concerts, a chamber ensemble based in Bellport. He was asked by Lisa Radakovich Holsberg, a soprano who teaches voice at Long Island University's C.W. Post campus in Brookville, to set to music poems written by ordinary people after Sept. 11, 2001, and found posted throughout New York City. They were collected by City Lore, a folk arts organization.
Mr. Thomas said that in composing the music, he felt a great responsibility to the poets, ''who were coming from very emotional places.''
''How could I be honest about my reaction to the attack, and respectful of their extremely personal reactions without being sentimental?'' he said.

Mr. Thomas and Ms. Holsberg chose three poems to set to music: ''To the Towers Themselves'' (anonymous); ''How My Life Has Changed'' by Hilary North, who worked in one of the towers; and ''Don't Look for Me Anymore'' by Alicia Vasquez.

Along with a violin solo, the three texts make up Mr. Thomas's suite, ''Race for the Sky.'' Sung by Deborah Birnbaum, a soprano, and with Mr. Thomas at the piano and Sarah Schwartz on violin, the suite is featured in a performance by South Country Concerts today at 5 p.m. at Christ Episcopal Church. The church is on South Country Road in Bellport. Information: (631)286-1592.
A Festival at Stony Brook

Graduate music students and faculty members at the State University of New York at Stony Brook are joining with members of the Emerson String Quartet, which is in residence on campus, to hold a Chamber Music Festival tomorrow through Saturday at Staller Center.
The festival includes workshops, master classes and performances, and ends with a concert on Saturday night at 8 featuring members of the quartet, students and faculty. Information: (631)632-2787.
'Mikado' Returns

The Gilbert & Sullivan Light Opera Company of Long Island last performed ''The Mikado'' 17 years ago. To celebrate the ensemble's 50th anniversary, the company brings the operetta to Long Beach High School on Saturday night at 8.
The group will perform the work again on May 22 at the Landmark on Main Street in Port Washington and on June 5 at Town Hall West in Islip. Information: (516)887-2802.
Celebrating Writers

The ''Meet the Writers'' Book Fair at Southampton College begins on Friday. Robert A. Caro will receive the Steinbeck Writers Award, and more than 90 local writers will be on hand for the event, held from 4 to 7:30 p.m. in a tent at Chancellors Hall. Information: (631)287-8347.
In Bloom
The annual ''Dutch Festival'' is today from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. at Hofstra University. There will be thousands of tulips in bloom, food, crafts and entertainment. Information: (516)463-6582.

The Huntington Arts Council presents its ''Tulip Festival'' today from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. That event is at Heckscher Park and features family-oriented performances and activities. Information: (631)271-8423.
The Garden Conservancy holds its first ''Open Day'' of the season today; five private gardens in Amagansett, Cutchogue and East Hampton will welcome visitors. Information: (888)842-2442.
Whirling Dervishes
The Whirling Dervishes of Turkey will perform at St. Joseph's College in Patchogue on Saturday. The event is at 7:30 p.m. in the D'Ecclesiis Auditorium in O'Connor Hall. Information: (631)447-3298.
Free Choices

TODAY -- Joined by Bennett Kramer, 16, a violinist from Belle Terre, and John Field, 18, a clarinetist from East Meadow, the Island Senior Symphony performs at 3 p.m. in the Van Nostrand Theater on the Brentwood campus of Suffolk Community College. (631)281-6243.
The American Chamber Ensemble plays at 2:30 p.m. at the Hewlett-Woodmere Library on Broadway in Hewlett. Information: (516)374-1967.
SATURDAY -- The Massapequa Philharmonic Orchestra, with Jon Klibonoff as piano soloist, performs at 8:30 p.m. at Berner Middle School on Carmans Mill Road. Information: (516)785-4071.
